column6: PDP Afterglow Wired Controller for Xbox 360
column14:
These controllers degrade fast during heavy use. Primarily the chord and the analog sticks. but also have noticed issues with the triggers as well. Other issues include my PC not entering into idle state (activating screensaver) when one of these controllers are plugged in to the system. regardless of power settings. This is a problem with all three of the afterglow controllers I own.

Lastly, A HUGE CONCERN: The USB plug on this controller will cause physical damage to a PC USB port due to the weight of the plug and of the cord itself. these plugs are designed in the same manner as the ones designed for the Xbox 360. on the 360 you have a piece of plastic about a half of an inch away from the female port that supports the weight of the controllers plug. on 99% of PC's you don't have that. Which can very quickly lead to a loosening of the USB port from the PCB board. which can result in both critical and catastrophic USB issues and hardware failure.
If you still intend on purchasing this controller I HIGHLY RECOMMENDED that you purchase a USB EXTENSION CORD that can be secured in such a way so that this controller does not cause severe and unnecessary physical strain on your USB ports.

column13: Okay, but not worth the price
column14:
When I first got Tomodachi Life I actually played it quite a bit. Maybe that was a mistake because I've had it for less than a week and I'm already bored with it. The game is very repetitive, and there is very little to do most of the time. You solve the same Mii problems, read the same dialogue, and play the same games everyday. There are daily events, but the events are the same everyday so even those lose their appeal after the first couple of days. While you do have some influence over your Miis, You can tell your Miis what you think of their relationships if they ask, but you can't tell them to go be friends with someone or ask them out if they don't already plan on it in the first place. People compare the game to Animal Crossing or The Sims, but it's much more like watching fish in a tank, if your fish wore clothes and had really weird dreams.

Despite my complaints, the game isn't terrible. There's a large amount of clothing, food, and room interiors to unlock, and different Miis will like different ones. The Miis themselves are able to be customized greatly as well. Aside from the regular Mii customization found on the 3DS, you are also able to give them a customized voice and one of 16 different personalities. All of this can be easily changed at any point in the game by just selecting the \\\Edit Mii\\\\\" option at either the Town Hall or in their rooms. You are also able to dye their hair various other colors not found in the Mii Maker by using a hairspray item given to you by your Miis after helping them out. There are several different things you can give as gifts when your Mii levels up as well, which they will then use in their apartments. Sometimes Miis will use these with their friends when they hang out together. I'll look in a room and see a group of Miis playing with a cat using a rent-a-cat coupon, or they'll be playing the Wii U (if you listen closely you might be able to recognize the games they're playing), or I'll see four Miis standingaround in a circle having a maraca party. There are other areas you can unlock as well, like a park, a cafe, and an amusement park, that Miis may hang out at.

Overall, I don't dislike the game, but once you see everything it loses it's appeal. It's a good game if you don't have a lot of time everyday and want something casual, as there is no consequence for not playing like there is in Animal Crossing, but I would recommend getting it at a cheaper price if you can. If you want a game that you can sit down and play for hours everyday, this isn't the game for you."

I endeavor to take as good of care as possible of my things to ensure that they last, but as you've probably read from other reviews, these will begin to crack along the thin plastic of the adjustable range of the earpiece, most likely within the first six months.

I've had mine probably about two years now (consistently taped) and they have just finally broken completely through and duct tape is the ONLY thing keeping my right earpiece attached to the headset right now besides the internal wiring. It still works, but now it's much less comfortable and I'm seeking a new headset. If you're fine with buying a new set of these over and over then these may be for you. If you want something that will last for years with good care, search elsewhere. These Turtle Beaches are notorious for this poor construction quality with weak materials, built to break.

TLDR; They're alright headphones but they'll break even with care. Be warned.

column13: Nvidia Shield - Windows Media Center is dying - is this the successor?
column14:
I bought the Shield as a replacement for my Windows Media Center primarily to watch movies, TV and listen to music. Playing games is low on the list so I have not really assessed this part of the Shield's capabilities.

As a media player this device is very accomplished for the range of formats it supports and the sheer speed of the device. I mostly use the Plex app which looks very nice and due to the Shield supporting many video codecs Plex can 'direct play' videos, negating the need to transcode on the fly. I also use Netflix in Ultra HD and this looks brilliant on my 70in UHD TV. I now prefer to watch TV shows available on Netflix in UHD compared to local free TV which in Australia rarely does Full HD, let alone UHD. One example is The Blacklist, watching this on Free Tv vs Netflix via the Shield in UHD is stunning in the difference. Whilst my Sony UHD TV has inbuilt UHD for Netflix, the Shield is simply faster and flawless in playback.

UHD on YouTube is growing in the catalog and the voice search works very, very well. This is far more convenient than reaching for a keyboard, which is also supported.

The device itself is virtually silent, looks great and the remote control (whilst costing extra) is a nice addition for media duties.

Many have commented on the lack of Apps in the Android TV Play Store and whilst I agree, the basic apps are there, an exception for my type of use is TV DVR features, live TV works well in a few different apps using network tuners from Silicon Dust who I understand are working on DVR features for Plex as part of a Kick-starter program.

The only feature holding me back from a full recommendation as a media player is the absence of audio bit streaming pass through. This has also been commented in other reviews and I see that Nvidia are planning this support in a future update. I keep checking for the updates everyday as once this bit streaming arrives it will have exceeded my Windows Media Center for day to day use and with the extra capability of flawless UHD, the Shield will be king of our lounge room.

column6: DRAGON QUEST 1 & 2 Nintendo Super Famicom Japan Game SFC
column13: One of the best SNES/SFC games available, and an amazing deal to boot!
column14:
Simply amazing! This is one single cart holding two of the best early console RPGs of all time, remastered for the 16 bit SNES. At the prices you can find this for online, there really is no question that you should purchase this, providing you can read Japanese or have some way to patch it with your prefered language. These are, in my opinion, some of the best RPGs of all time. There is not job or class system here; this is just good old fashioned monster killing at its best. If you enjoy this game, I would also highly recommend ordering the third game for the SNES as well, as all three fit into a single trilogy.
Beyond the third, if you are looking to further explore the series, I would simply hunt down copies of 4-6 for the Nintendo DS. 7-8 are reported to be coming to the 3DS by the end of 2016, and 9 was originally released for the Nintendo DS. 10, however, is only available in Japan, as it is an MMO, though a possible offline version of it could reach the west at some point, which has been rumored. Finally, 11 has been announced for PS4, and NX (Nintendo's unnamed next generation console), with a 3DS version that plays similarly to the classic games in the series also being released.

Destiny game is packed with thrill and excitement. The graphics of the game are insane. I highly recommend this game.

If you play games primarily for story or characters do not buy this game. If you play games primarily for a sense of exploration or to see breath taking environments, do not buy this game. If you have zero patience for grinding do not buy this game.

However if you play games primarily for combat mechanics then this might be the game for you. Combat is hardly perfect in this game, but it is where this game shines, especially since each character has their own unique take on it. This game is deeply flawed, but this one aspect was enough to turn it around into an enjoyable experience for me.

The other good thing I can say about it is that, while grinding is required, it isn't nearly that much. If you've ever grinded in a game and not minded that much then you'll probably be okay with its use here.

Probably the most disappointment part of this game to me, is the way it discourages exploration. You keep teleporting back to your school at the end of every mission, so you keep seeing the same places. You do get your airship to fly you around to other regions (don't get too excited it's just a cutscene then teleport) but without traveling on the tedious overworld map for far too long you still can't get much of anywhere. And trust me the overworld map is tedious.

You walk slow, and the random encounters there are as generic as they come. The chobo's mitigate this issue, but since you have a limited number of them and the last for a limited time, you still won't want to explore. Especially since there are level 99 enemies running around the world map. If they catch you you're screwed. They are fairly easy to avoid but to someone who hasn't seen them before newly exploring and area and getting destroyed for it it feels like an "F you" from the developers.

Also you have entirely too much downtime between missions. I get they wanted something else to break up the action, but the missions are by far the best part, yet if you just jump straight to the next one you'll die. Oh and this game lacks polish in a number of small areas as well.

Just be careful not to lose the special little paper with the code!

And if you are on the fence about spending your money on the WiiU... honestly, it's worth it. I wanted it since it was released so I waited forever to save up the money, and when I had it I felt like I was holding blacks of gold. The use of the gamepad is innovative and so much fun, and the motion controls on it work like a dream. It communicates directly with the WiiU so you don't have to worry about juggling the sensor bar. And the graphics!!! Using an HDMI cable, it's all 1080p, and it is absolutely pristine and beautiful, I was completely in awe. (If you don't have that connection you do have the option of using other AV cables, but they don't come included (the HDMI cables do of course) so if you want to start playing right away without the HDMI then you'll need those beforehand.) Miiverse is a super cute little community and it's cool tosee what other players all around the world are saying! There's so many games out for it right now, so you have plenty to play, and you also have the option of moving all your Wii data to the new system - of course it's backwards compatible with the Wii games, but not gamecube I don't think.

Now if it's the game you're on the fence about: Splatoon is a game I have been dying to play. it's not a typical action shooter at all - it's incredibly fun and varied and interesting, and I find it can be either intense and exciting or very chill and calming depending on your mindset while playing. The whole game really focuses on positivity, so it's wonderful for all ages. there's a whole lot of buttons but after just a couple matches you'll see how quickly you get the hang of it. It's my favorite game hands down right now. I recommend looking at some gameplay videos on YT if you're unsure how you feel about it just by what you read! (And honestly, if you're buying a WiiU anyway, you should get this one since you're paying the same price as getting a regular one, but you have this game to try out and if you don't like it too much you're not losing anything.)

All in all I was not disappointed by this amazing system, and I wholeheartedly give my vote right here for best price and service :)

column13: There's a reason this headset has dropped in price.
column14:
I bought this one on Groupon thinking I was getting some slamming deal, as I remember them being over $50 when they were first released, and I also needed a new headset to replace my old Logitech one (they do NOT make their products to last like they used to).

So out of the box, they look great. Some people here hate the mesh on the phones themselves, but I think they're comfy. The part that's not comfy? The fact that you feel like you're wearing a vice on your head after you put them on. I'm going to echo the other reviewers on here when I say that these things are TIGHT. Tighter than any other headphones I've worn, and the only thing that's adjustable are the phones, not the headpiece they're connected to. So if your head is bigger than a 12 year old's, then these will not be comfortable. I couldn't return them, so I've been slowly stretching the plastic (to the point of hearing it crack) to get these to fit better. Because that's what I bought these for. To manhandle them into fitting.

Also it only took about 20-30 minutes of wearing these before I started getting a headache. The other reviewers here aren't kidding or being sissies, this is a common problem because they're so tight.

So next up, another huge problem I haven't seen addressed, is the 7.1 sound. Or not really the sound, as the sound quality is great - that's one of the only things this has going for it. No, it's the volume control device. This thing lets out an earth-shattering, you'll-feel-like-Carlos-in-Freddy's-Dead (look it up) BEEEEEEEEP!!!!!! noise that will only add to your discomfort of wearing these if you have to change the volume, or hit the mute button. Even if you're lowering the volume, the actual beep you'll hear in the headset is not going to change and will be as obnoxiously loud as ever. Why that had to be added is beyond me. With any other device, I can tell when I'm lowering or raising the volume because the sound will ACTUALLY get louder or quieter, and if it doesn't, then that's a good indicator something's wrong. I don't need that extra sound to help me.

I haven't used the mic, but that thing looks super flimsy so I'm not touching it. I also don't usually talk to people on PSN because most people online annoy the crap out of me. Supposedly the mic goes to mute when you retract it back into the headset, which knowing my luck, I can see that being the first thing to break and then everybody could hear me regardless.

So ultimately, for $20-$25, you can certainly do better than these. Look at more Amazon reviews and even plunk down some extra money and buy better phones. I read some excellent reviews of the HyperX Cloud II headphones, maybe start there, but they're also like $70 more. So maybe you get what you pay for. I don't know.

column6: Lords of the Fallen: Limited Edition - PlayStation 4
column14:
Some people have called this a poor man's Dark Souls. That's a pretty accurate description.

In ways, it tops the Souls series. The graphics and presentation are top notch and the story is actually coherent.

But in all other ways it falls short of the Souls series' glory. The single most frustrating aspect to me was that the maps are incredibly easy to get lost in. The Souls games never provided any type of map for you to view but for the most part the pathways to and from places were pretty intuitive. Not the case in LotF. There is no variety in the locales, it's either crumbly castles or snowy peaks, and after a while it all starts to look the same. This problem is compounded at the end of the game when you have to find 3 levers to access the final boss. There is nothing that tells you that you need to find levers, no hint at where they are, and the levers themselves tend to blend into the wall textures. Probably 1/3 of my logged time in the game was just going through the same corridors and hallways I'd been down 100 times just trying to figure out what to do or how to get back to an area I'd already been.

I found most of the equipment in the game to be useless. There are a handful of weapons in the game that stand head and shoulders above the others, rendering all of the others utterly useless. Sadly there is no option to sell or dismantle weapons, so they just sit in your inventory taking up space. You'll find a treasure chest and crack it open with excitement only to see that it's a weapon worse than what you already have, and with no way to sell it, it's a paper weight.

You can invest XP in either improving attributes like strength, agility, vitality, etc. or you can invest them in learning & improving spells. The spells are incredibly useful and almost seem to undermine physical combat. You can learn only 4 spells however, and once you've maxed them out, there is no use in investing XP in magic anymore. This became frustrating when I found a spell point shard that I couldn't even use because my spells were already maxed out. Add that shard to the other useless items in my inventory.

There were times when actions seemed unresponsive, which became frustrating when trying to evade a boss' attacks. Not sure WHY my character wouldn't roll when I clearly pressed the X button. It wasn't an extremely frequent problem but in a game where every dodge and attack can be the difference in winning or dying, yeah, it's pretty frustrating. (And I don't think it's my controller because I've never had unresponsive buttons before).

Camera angles become problematic in cramped corridors. Not only does it make locking onto an enemy hard, especially if they're very near you, but often times the enemy's health bar would float just above the screen making it impossible to tell if your attacks were effective or if the enemy was one more swing away from dying.

All is not bad in the game though. It does still provide some satisfying Souls style combat, but it lacks Souls'.... well... soul. I got the game for $24.00 and I'm glad I didn't pay more. column13: Not nearly as good as Fable 2
column14: The graphics are really excellent for a 360 game.  Game play is good too.  But if you've played through Fable and Fable 2, and you're expecting something similar, you'll be disappointed.  They changed just enough to tick me off.  For starters, there's a lot more story, which is fine if you want to watch a movie, but I was hoping to play a game.  The process by which you go about buying items is cumbersome and limited, as you actually look at items on pedestals in shops, which leaves you with about 4 options (or even one) from each vendor.  So, rather than sorting through a nice list of 30 weapons from a particular weapon trader, you go into a shop and look at 2-4.  And the best weapons are the ones you start with anyway, as they change as your skills increase.  Navigating the options menu isn't a menu at all, but a "room" called the "sanctuary", where you walk into a door to see your wardrobe options, another door to see your weapons, etc.  It's creative and bold, and I suppose I'm glad someone tried it, but it's no fun.  Fable 2 was probably the best game I've played in a very long time.  Fable 3 was a huge disappointment.  Also, it's short.  I played through the whole main story in about 8 hours.  And, once you've finished the main story, your other options are limited based on the way the game ended, which, as you know, will vary depending on your choices.  So, I played through it a second time.  I made different choices.  It wasn't much more fun.  Bah.  You can decide.

column14:
$300 is A LOT to pay for a headset. There's NO getting around that fact, but that large price tag is MUCH easier to swallow when the product performs as well as these do. I am the proud owner of a high end 7.1 Klipsch home theater, but unfortunately as a town-home owner that is attached to 2 neighboring houses, I don't get the opportunity to crank the sound to necessary "action" volumes. Sound is such a HUGE part of the immersion experience for both movies and video games, that I felt like I was missing out on the intended experience.

Enter the Turtle Beach Ear Force Elite 800x Headset.... these things are AWESOME. I was slightly concerned that setting up the headset would be difficult with my current audio setup, but it was literally plugging in 3 cables; 1) USB from the included transmitter to the XBOX One, 2) Optical cable from the XBOX to the transmitter, and 3) Optical cable from the transmitter to my amplifier..... that's it. The setup couldn't have been easier and the results are sheer audio pleasure. I would HIGHLY recommend that you update the firmware on the included transmitter to fully open up customizable audio options for your headset. This can easily be done by visiting the Turtle Beach website and following the step-by-step instructions.

The audio quality is tight and distortion free even at the higher volumes and comes with various presets depending on what type of movie or game you are using them for. All of these presets can be adjusted on the fly using either the touch sensitive buttons on both of the ear cups, or by using your phone or tablet with the Elite Audio Turtle Beach app. Personally I prefer the app as it is MUCH easier and slightly more intuitive to use.

The ear cups are comfortable for long gaming sessions, but the headset is slightly on the heavy side and can result in a pressure point on the top of your head, but I only really have an issue with this during marathon sessions of 6 hoursor more. Charge time for the internal battery is quick, and lasts longer than expected.

Overall, the best thing that I can say about this headset is that it has replaced my Klipsch home theater setup for the majority of my gaming and solo movie watching needs. I am FINALLY able to get that fully immersive experience, and it has made my digital media consumption THAT much more enjoyable. In my eyes, the price is ABSOLUTELY worth the money if you use movies, TV shows or video games to unwind after an exhausting or stressful day. Treat yourself and get that movie theater experience without ever leaving the comfort of your own home.

column6: Child of Light - PlayStation Vita Standard Edition
column13: A Beautiful Fairy Tale Well Worth Playing
column14:
Child of Light is a beautiful Ubisoft game that terribly wants to be an "indie" game. The Vita version is currently the *only* physical release of the game. (Why Ubisoft choose the Vita of all platforms is a mystery.) So, if you are looking for a physical version then this is your only choice. That said, this is just as beautiful a game on the Vita as on any other platform. In fact, this is without doubt one of the best games on the Vita. Although the game has some problems, which is why I did not give it a five-star rating, I nevertheless highly recommend playing this game. Overall, I would rate it at 4.25 out of 5 stars. Let me explain why:

GRAPHICS
=========
First thing you will notice about the game is that it is downright gorgeous. The game looks like a living watercolor painting, which is exactly what the producers were aiming for. If the graphics seem similar to some Japanese games, then again, that is also what they producers were aiming for. Although this was produced in Montreal, it is inspired by Japanese role-playing games (such as Odin Sphere). Regardless, the graphics are spectacular.

MUSIC
======
Next thing you will notice is the music. The music is by Cœur de pirate (Béatrice Martin) and it is perfect (well, almost)! The music is very piano-centered. It is dreamy, surreal and slightly sad. The exception are some of the boss battle musics which sound like they were taken right out of a Japanese RPG (think Final Fantasy). The boss battle music is beautiful, but personally I feel it is out of place in the game. While the rest of the music makes you feel like you're in a fantasy dreamland, the boss battles make you feel like you're playing most any Japanese RPG. That said, I still love the soundtrack! It really does fit the fairy tale like atmosphere of the game. OK, now for the story...

STORY
======
It's a beautiful story. It really is a fairy tale brought to life. Like most fairy tales the story is fairly simple and generic. You have monsters, a princess, sickness, good and evil. Don't expect the game to change your view on life. However, that said, much like fairy tales the game is a reflection/meditation about life, death, and purpose. It's simple enough that a young child can enjoy, and deep enough for an older individual (such as myself). Now... how fun is the game? Let's talk about gameplay.

GAMEPLAY
=========
When I first played the game, I expected the game to be an action-RPG based on screenshots I saw. I was surprised to learn that it's turn-based. You "bump" into a monster and you start a battle. It has a real-time bar and you can see when your characters will act and when the monsters will act. If you time things properly, you can stop the monsters from attacking and in essence attack until they are defeated (well, that's the goal). Sometimes you will succeed, sometimes you will fail. If one of your part members falls, no big deal. You can replace him/her with another party member who will join the fight at full health. Sounds like the battles are easy? For the most part they are. They're also fairly repetitive. While certainly not bad, they do get old, which is one reason why I simply can not give this game 5 stars. You will do a lot of fighting. Some of the boss battles are beautiful and quite enjoyable, but for the most part you'll simply be grinding past enemies. Apart from battles what else is there?

Side-Quests: The game does have side-quests, and for the most part they are very simple. Defeat these bad guys. Go back to where you were previously and find this or that. Not particularly exciting. That said, it's nice that they added these to the game. Unfortunately, you may find that you spend more time looking for said object simply because you know it's somewhere in the forest, but where? There are NO maps in the game! For the most part it's not a big deal, but it would have beenhelpful to have a map with highlights on it. Another complaint, the voice-acting or lack thereof.

Voice-Acting: This game is told in a lyrical style. Everything that is said by any character basically rhymes. It would have been beautiful to hear professional voice actors speak the lines! While not all games have to have voice acting, I think for Child of Light it would really add to the dreamlike fairy tale quality. Besides, it's not hard to add an option to turn voice acting off if one so wanted. However, as it stands, there is almost no voice acting. Remember, this is not a small indie game, it was produced by Ubisoft so it's not as if it was beyond their budget!

Linear Game: There are basically almost no choices in the game. While this is not necessarily a bad thing, there is very little character development. There certainly is some, especially for the heroine, Aurora. However, for the most part you just listen to what people have to say and that's about it. I wish there were a few more choices and we would get to learn more about the characters.

Crafting: Child of Light has no weapons, no armor, and in fact you can not purchase anything! However, you can find lots of "Oculi" which are basically jewels that you can strengthen and combine to form more powerful jewels that can be equipped to give you certain bonuses. For example, a crude diamond can give the equipped character 5% extra experience. However, a diamond that has been crafted from stronger components will give 10% extra experience, and so on. It's cute. Unfortunately, there is no guide to crafting, and nothing in the manual. Which is to say, no manual. Which leads me to discuss, what exactly are you getting here that you're not getting elsewhere?

VITA Features
===========
Apart from the fact that you are getting a physical version of the game, you are NOT getting anything new. Thus, if you already have a downloaded version of the game, you will find nothing new here. No exclusive characters. No exclusive locations. No bonus anything. In fact, not even a flimsy manual (cheap of you, Ubisoft, cheap). Well, I suppose in this day and age we should be thankful we have a physical copy so that we can loan it to friends or gift it. Still... would it really hurt to add something exclusive, maybe just a map or manual?

Final Thoughts
============
Yes, I do have some complaints as noted above. That said, this is still a game that is worth supporting (tell Ubisoft we want more such games) and certainly worth playing (simple, yet engaging and beautiful game). Perhaps there shall be a sequel, and perhaps some of my complaints will be answered. I do hope there is a sequel, because this really is a wonderful game and it's refreshing to play something that not only has a strong female lead (you go, Aurora!) but is charming.

column13: Seemed like a lot of recycled material
column14: Seemed like a lot of recycled material. Combat is pretty boring- basically just spam attacks, be ready press the block button, and dodge/stop gun shots. Combat also seemed kind of clunky/slow compared to other AC games. French storyline is okay, but I hate how they didnt take the user outside the Animus in this one. It was like a teaser by having more and more control over Desmond across the original series and then killing him off only to be replaced by a random Animus user. Now your "character" is just some other Animus beta tester who is supposed to relive the adventures of random assassins not at all related to him. They've either thrown out the idea of a character like Desmond who can relive his own ancestors' past lives and then become an assassin himself in the game's real world or they're saving their modern assassin for a much later game (which also sucks since that implies Ubisoft intends to milk the series for as long as possible and draw out the overarching plot for far too long before delivering a conclusion that fans want). To me, the game's redeeming qualities are its ability to allow a player to freely run around a well-constructed open world environment and the fun storyline of reliving the past in order to stop a present day evil organization. Bringing those god-like beings into the story and having them somehow interact with Desmond while he was reliving a memory was odd, but okay. But then they decide to kill off the guy you've been following the entire time and who they've hyped up as being some "chosen one", too. Since the last pirate expansion, they've slowed the game's modern day plot to a standstill with all the games basically being "oh look you're a beta tester and the templar organization is releasing a random new assassin memory so you should go live it. Maybe you'll see something that these templars didn't somehow already find prior to releasing it that can lead us on a hunt for a golden apple thing. Don't worry withthe real world hunt and evil organization, though. Just spend the whole time in the Animus and when you're all done we'll give you a pat on the back and move on to asking some other random person for help". So yeah, they kind of butchered one of the major things that it had going for it. By the time I bought this, though, Ubisoft patched all the really troubling bugs (which would have really pissed me off if I got this at full retail on release day) so at least I got it for cheap.
